newsitem.title: USA: Hackers leave print on "Lost World".
newsitem.headline: Hackers leave print on "Lost World".

text.p: The opening page for the Web site for the film "The Lost World: Jurassic Park" wasn't all it was quacked up to be after hackers got through with it Tuesday.
In place of the film's trademark dinosaur logo was a profile of a prehistoric-looking duck, accompanied by the title "The Lost Pond: Jurassic Duck."
As if there was any doubt, the pranksters left a one-word calling card: "hackers.:"

"I thought it was amusing," Alan Sutton, Universal Studios vice president for distribution and marketing, said in a telephone interview Wednesday. "The Lost World: Jurassic Park" was put out by Universal, a subsidiary of the Seagram Co. Ltd.
The site's home page -- http://www.lost-world.com -- was altered sometime Tuesday.
Sutton said a colleague in New York alerted him to the hacker prank Wednesday morning. Sutton told technicians, who restored the page to its original appearance, snarling dinosaur and all.
"We're taking a closer look at our firewalls, obviously," he said, referring to computer network security.
The movie executive said he had no plans to pursue the pranksters.
"It was just done in a spirit of fun," Sutton said.
